thread.title: TN bill would ban teaching 'religious doctrine' until high school
thread.title_full: TN bill would ban teaching 'religious doctrine' until high school

title: TN bill would ban teaching 'religious doctrine' until high school
text:
GOP presidential contender Carson returning to Franklin Dave Boucher , dboucher@tennessean.com 1:24 p.m. CDT October 9, 2015 GOP presidential contender Ben Carson (left) received a tour of Franklin recently from Mayor Ken Moore. Moore is hosting a fundraiser for Carson at his home on Oct. 31. (Photo: File / Shelley Mays / The Tennessean) 241 CONNECT 13 TWEET 3 LINKEDIN 2 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
GOP presidential contender Ben Carson is set to return to Williamson County for a Halloween fundraiser, according to an announcement from the Williamson County Republican Party. 
The "coffee and conversation" with Carson is set for 9 a.m. Oct. 31 at the home of Franklin Mayor Ken Moore. Moore led Carson on a tour of Franklin at the end of August, where the former surgeons appeared to bond. Ben Carson speaks, plays tourist in Franklin 
The trip to Republican-heavy Williamson County comes as Carson's star continues to rise. But that spike in national polling is joined by an increase in national criticism related to comments on guns. The soft-spoken Carson drew ire after he said he would've rushed the gunman at the Oregon community college shooting, and after he said the Holocaust would have been "greatly diminished" if the people of Germany were armed. 
On Friday morning, Moore said that he didn't know the context of those statements, so he didn't feel it was fair to comment on them. 
When he met with Carson, he said he found him to be, "extremely intelligent," well-informed and patriotic. 
"He is an American story," Moore said of Carson. "He's someone who had a very difficult upbringing and reached the pinnacle of being a pediatric neurosurgeon -- so, wow." 
Still, Moore stopped shy of endorsing Carson. 
"I'm still working through that entire process," he said. "There's a long time until the convention."
